p: Biomedical research on emergent infectious diseases would benefit from what invasion science can offer in terms of, for example, (i) a consolidated array of frameworks for studying the consequences of eco-evolutionary novelty, specifically the release of organisms lacking ecological analogues in their recipient environments [ 4]; (ii) expanding knowledge of the eco-evolutionary factors that determine the success of transitions between stages of invasion ( Figure 1), which are influenced by a combination of human activities, environmental conditions, and their feedbacks [ 4, 11, 12]; and (iii) a rich literature on the context-dependent dynamics and predictive modeling of organismal spread and their effects.
